The text is quite clear when it comes to what constitutes the space, i.e., the model entities, i.e., squares, habitat cells. Also, there is a list of the variables characterising the space. Finally, the variables are initialised in the text to particular values. This makes it easy to extract the required information using Python libraries like re and nltk.Code for extracting all variables along with the initialisation details:'''# import necessary python packagesimport re # Regular expression libraryimport json # Library for writing in JSON formatimport nltk # Natural Language Processing librarydef parse():    '''    Extracts all the relevant details about the space and the variables    '''    # Open file for reading    infile = open('abm_text.txt', "r")    # Read contents    data = infile.read()    # Create list of all the space-related sentences    space_sentences = []    # Look for sentences starting with the word Space    regex_pattern_space = re.compile(r'Space\s*(\w+)(?!.*\(a\.k\.a|space)', re.IGNORECASE)    matches_list_space = regex_pattern_space.finditer(data) # List of match objects    for match_obj in matches_list_space:        # Match text        match_txt = match_obj.group(0)        # Append to list of space sentences        space_sentences.append(match_txt)        # Create list of all variable-related sentences    var_sentences = []    # Look for sentences starting with the word Variables    regex_pattern_var = re.compile(r'Variables\s*\w+', re.IGNORECASE)    matches_list_var = regex_pattern_var.finditer(data) # List of match objects    for match_obj in matches_list_var:        # Match text        match_txt = match_obj.group(0)        # Append to list of var sentences        var_sentences.append(match_txt)    # Get initialisation text    init_text = ""    # Find line breaks after each sentence that mentions Variable name    regex_pattern_name_init = re.compile(r'
